questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, distention, and fever. He reports having bloody diarrhea and has been using mesalamine and prednisone to manage his condition. On physical examination, his abdomen is tender and distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory tests indicate leukocytosis and electrolyte imbalances. An erect abdominal X-ray was taken as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Toxic megacolon

 

Option D:

 

Dilated transverse and descending colon, with loss of characteristic haustrations is suggestive of toxic megacolon. The upper limit of normal bowel diameter for small bowel is 3 cm, for large bowel 6 cm and for cecum 9 cm.

 

The most widely used criteria for the clinical diagnosis of toxic megacolon are:

 

Radiographic evidence of colonic distension PLUS at least three of the following:

 

  • Fever > 38°C
  • Heart rate > 120/min
  • Neutrophilic leukocytosis >10,500/uL
  • Anemia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pneumatosis intestinalis involves the presence of gas cysts in the bowel wall, which is not indicated in this X-ray.

 

Option B: Perforation peritonitis would show free air under the diaphragm, which is not visible here.

 

Option C: Diverticulitis typically presents with localized colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat stranding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic radiographic findings of dilated colon segments and clinical symptoms suggest toxic megacolon, especially in a patient with a history of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Ref: Page no-292, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 36-week gestation newborn is born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 28-year-old primigravida mother. The pregnancy was uneventful with normal antenatal ultrasound findings. The newborn is noted to have respiratory distress immediately after delivery and is quickly transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for further evaluation and management. On examination, the neonate is tachypneic with subcostal retractions and decreased breath sounds on the left side. CXR is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

  • An X-ray of the chest shows a left-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)-Bochdalek type with the stomach and intestines occupying the left chest cavity and compressing the left lung. 
  • There is a defect in posterior-lateral aspect of the left pleuroperitoneal canal from which the diaphragm develops. 
  • This allows the abdominal contents to herniate into the chest cavity, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory distress.

 

Initial management: 

 

  • The neonate is started on mechanical ventilation, and a nasogastric tube is inserted for decompression of the stomach. 
  • The neonate is also started on a prostaglandin infusion to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus and optimize pulmonary blood flow. 
  • The neonate is stabilized and is taken up for surgical repair of the diaphragmatic hernia within the first few days of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary hypoplasia: Underdevelopment of the lungs usually associated with other conditions.

 

Option C. Trachea esophageal fistula: An abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus.

 

Option D. Eventration of the diaphragm: Thinning and elevation of part of the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The correct diagnosis is congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which presents with respiratory distress and is confirmed by the presence of abdominal organs in the thoracic cavity on X-ray. 
  • Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to the risk of gastrointestinal perforation and worsening respiratory distress.

 

Note â€“ Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty swallowing for the past few months. He reports feeling as if food is getting stuck in his chest and he has to drink liquids to help it go down. He also reports regurgitation of undigested food and occasional chest pain. He denies any weight loss, heartburn, or reflux symptoms. On examination, his vital signs are within normal limits, and he appears well-nourished. Auscultation of the lungs is clear, and there are no abdominal masses or hepatosplenomegaly. A barium swallow study is ordered, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Achalasia cardia 

 

Option C:

 

Achalasia cardia typically presents with a dilated esophagus and a narrowed gastroesophageal junction creating a "bird-beak" sign, as seen in the image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Diffuse esophageal spasm would show a corkscrew appearance on imaging, not seen here.

 

Option B: A hiatus hernia would show a protrusion of the stomach through the diaphragm into the thorax.

 

Option D: Carcinoma of the esophagus usually shows as an irregular narrowing or a stricture, commonly with a "rat-tail" appearance, which is not apparent in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The barium swallow study demonstrates a "bird-beak" sign, indicating achalasia cardia, a condition characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax and the absence of normal esophageal peristalsis

 

 

Ref: Page no-248, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of left lower quadrant abdominal pain that has been present for several days. He also reports constipation, bloating, and occasional rectal bleeding. On examination, there is tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the likely diagnosis based on his barium enema?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sigmoid diverticulosis

 

Option A:

 

The clinical presentation and imaging findings in this patient are consistent with sigmoid diverticulosis. The presence of multiple diverticula in the sigmoid colon is a hallmark feature of sigmoid diverticulosis. The patient's constipation, bloating, and rectal bleeding are also common symptoms associated with sigmoid diverticulosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Sigmoid volvulus would present with severe abdominal pain and distention, and a plain abdominal X-ray would show a characteristic "coffee bean" sign. S

 

Option C: Sigmoid diverticulitis would present with fever, leukocytosis, and localized abdominal pain, and imaging would show evidence of inflammation or abscess formation.

 

Option D: Colorectal cancer would typically present with a change in bowel habits, rectal bleeding, and possible mass on digital rectal examination or imaging. Which of the following condition shows ‘Saw tooth appearance’ on abdominal barium enema X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sigmoid diverticulosis is characterized by the presence of multiple diverticula seen in the sigmoid colon on barium enema imaging, consistent with the symptoms and the X-ray findings shown for the patient. This condition is associated with symptoms like constipation, bloating, and occasional rectal bleeding.

 

Ref: Page no-304, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

choices.text: Admit the patient to the ward and observe

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. He reports a recent history of non-compliance with his prescribed proton pump inhibitor medication. On examination, he appears pale and has a rigid abdomen with rebound tenderness. CXR of the patient is shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Perform immediate exploratory laparotomy

 

Option C:

 

Free air under the diaphragm on an erect chest X-ray is a hallmark sign of perforation. In this clinical scenario, the patient's history of peptic ulcer disease and recent non-compliance with medication suggest a possible perforated peptic ulcer. Given the patient's acute presentation and clinical examination findings of a rigid abdomen with rebound tenderness, immediate exploratory laparotomy is the next best step in management. This will allow for identification and repair of the perforation and possible removal of any contaminated tissue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Admission for observation is not appropriate for a surgical emergency indicated by free air under the diaphragm.

 

Option B: While intravenous antibiotics are part of the management, they are not the immediate next step given the need for urgent surgery.

 

Option D: Administration of analgesia and proton pump inhibitors is secondary to addressing the cause of the perforation surgically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a rigid abdomen and radiographic evidence of free air, suggesting a perforated peptic ulcer, the immediate next step is exploratory laparotomy to address the perforation.

 

Ref: Page no-252, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation. He also reports occasional shortness of breath and chest pain. On examination, the patient has decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest. Chest X-ray is shown here.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chilaiditi syndrome.

 

Option B:

 

Chilaiditi syndrome is a rare condition that occurs when the colon is interposed between the liver and the right hemidiaphragm, resulting in radiographic evidence of gas-filled loops of bowel in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. It is one of the causes of pseudo pneumoperitoneum. Colonic gas in this position may be misinterpreted as true pneumoperitoneum.

 

Patients with Chilaiditi syndrome can present with recurrent abdominal pain, bloating, constipation, and occasional respiratory symptoms such as shortness of breath and chest pain. The decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest are likely due to compression of the lung by the displaced colon.

 

Chilaiditi syndrome is the interposition of the colon between the liver and right diaphragm can cause symptoms like those described and would show elevated bowel loops on imaging.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bochdalek hernia: Typically presents at birth as a congenital defect, causing severe respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Morgagni hernia: Another type of diaphragmatic hernia, usually congenital, but less likely to cause these symptoms.

 

Option D. Large bowel obstruction: Would show dilated bowel loops and possibly air-fluid levels, but not typically associated with decreased breath sounds unless complicated by massive dilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chilaiditi syndrome is diagnosed when symptomatic interposition of the colon between the liver and diaphragm is present, as suggested by the patient's symptoms and X-ray findings.

 

Ref: Page no-392, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A patient with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain presents to the emergency department. The patient is hypotensive, tachycardic, and appears to be in distress. A chest x-ray is performed and shows free air under the diaphragm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Perforated peptic ulcer.

 

Option C.

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on chest x-ray is highly suggestive of pneumoperitoneum, which indicates the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity. Perforated peptic ulcer is a common cause of pneumoperitoneum, and is characterized by sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, which may be associated with nausea, vomiting, and hemodynamic instability.

 

Perforated peptic ulcer: Commonly presents with sudden severe abdominal pain and can cause pneumoperitoneum, evidenced by free air under the diaphragm on X-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute pancreatitis: Usually presents with epigastric pain that can radiate to the back, not typically associated with free air under the diaphragm.

 

Option B. Mesenteric ischemia: Causes abdominal pain and can lead to bowel infarction, but does not typically show free air under the diaphragm unless there's bowel perforation.

 

Option D. Pneumonia: A respiratory condition that does not cause free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and radiographic findings of free air under the diaphragm is a perforated peptic ulcer, a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention.

 

Ref: Page no-392, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to her gastroenterologist with a history of intermittent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss over the past several months. She reports that the pain is mainly in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen and is sometimes associated with nausea and vomiting. She has also noticed some blood in her stool. She denies any history of fever or recent travel. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant with no palpable masses or organomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). BMFT of the patient is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis in the patient shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Crohn's disease

 

Option B:

 

The patient's history, examination findings, and a long segment of terminal ileum which is narrowed with irregular margins on barium are all suggestive of Crohn's disease.

 

The location and appearance of this narrowed segment is characteristic of Crohn's Disease. This long-narrowed segment would qualify as the "string-sign" of persistent spasm seen with that disease. Crohn's most often affects the terminal ileum and has a bimodal age distribution. Surgery is usually avoided because of the propensity for recurrence at the site of the neo-terminal ileum. 

 

Crohn's disease

 

IOC → CT Enterography

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scleroderma: May cause bowel changes due to fibrosis but would not typically present with the acute symptoms described.

 

Option C. Carcinoma of the colon: Usually presents with a localized mass and narrowing, which may lead to obstruction; can be associated with weight loss and blood in the stool but has a different appearance on imaging.

 

Option D. Ulcerative colitis: Involves continuous colonic segments, typically starting from the rectum and moving proximally, not usually affecting the ileum as Crohn's disease does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Crohn's disease is suggested by the patient's symptoms and the characteristic "string sign" on the barium meal follow-through, indicative of inflammation and narrowing in the terminal ileum.

 

 

Ref: Page no- 276, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the patient shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Gastric Ulcer

 

Option B:

 

There is collection of barium along the lesser curvature of the barium-filled stomach which projects beyond the anticipated boundary of the lumen of the stomach. In addition, there is a linear radiolucency that is seen to traverse the collection. These findings are characteristic of a gastric ulcer and the linear lucency (Hampton's line) is the manifestation of the undermined mucosa almost always associated with a benign gastric ulcer. Most lesser curvature gastric ulcers are benign.

 

Gastric ulcer – The barium collection along the lesser curvature with a linear radiolucency, or Hampton's line, is indicative of a benign gastric ulcer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gastric carcinoma: Would typically appear as an irregular mass or filling defect in the stomach, not as a collection with a radiolucent line.

 

Option C. Gastric polyp: Generally, appears as a well-defined round or oval filling defect within the barium pool and does not produce a Hampton's line.

 

Option D. Gastrinoma: A type of tumor that may cause ulcers due to excess acid production but is not diagnosed through this imaging feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray findings of a barium collection along the lesser curvature with a linear radiolucency, known as Hampton's line, are characteristic of a benign gastric ulcer.

 

 

Ref: Page no-252, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the barium swallow shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Caustic stricture
 

Option C:

 

The esophagus appears to be smoothly narrowed over an extensive segment, from just below the clavicles to the gastroesophageal (GE) junction, which is indicative of a stricture caused by the ingestion of a corrosive substance. Such substances can lead to full-thickness liquefaction necrosis of the esophagus, followed by a fibrotic phase that occurs a few weeks after the acute ulcerative phase.

 

Caustic stricture – Can result in a smoothly narrowed esophagus due to scarring and stricture formation after corrosive injury, aligning with the image presented.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Reflux esophagitis: Often presents with inflammation seen as thickened mucosal folds or erosions, not typically showing a smoothly narrowed esophagus.

 

Option B. Fibrovascular polyp: Usually appears as a mass within the lumen of the esophagus, distinct from the smooth narrowing seen here.

 

Option D. Esophageal carcinoma: Generally shows as an irregular or nodular mass, possibly with a stricture, but would not usually cause extensive smooth narrowing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis suggested by a barium swallow showing extensive, smooth narrowing of the esophagus from just below the clavicles to the GE junction is consistent with a caustic stricture, likely due to ingestion of a corrosive substance.

 

Ref: Page no-240, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female presents to the gastroenterology clinic with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps for the past 2 weeks. She has been experiencing increased frequency of bowel movements with a sense of incomplete evacuation. The patient reports feeling fatigued and has lost a significant amount of weight over the past few months. On examination, the patient appears pale and there is tenderness over the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.

 

A colonoscopy is performed and reveals evidence of inflammation in the mucosal layer of the colon, with friability, erythema, and mucosal ulcerations extending proximally from the rectum. What earliest sign seen on Barium study in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mucosal Granularity

 

Option D:

 

Ulcerative colitis

 

 

 

  • Continuous involvement of colon (mucosal /submucosal involvement)-Loss of haustrations called lead pipe colon
  • Earliest sign on barium: diffuse mucosal granularity

 

Mucosal Granularity – An early sign in ulcerative colitis, representing fine, stippled appearance on the barium study due to inflammatory changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Collar Button Ulcers: More typical of Crohn’s disease, appearing as deep ulcerations that may extend through the bowel wall.

 

Option B. Haustral Loss: Occurs later in ulcerative colitis, leading to a ‘lead pipe’ appearance of the colon.

 

Option C. Pseudo-Polyps: Arise due to the healing of ulcerations, seen in more advanced disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The earliest sign of ulcerative colitis on a barium study is often mucosal granularity, reflecting the initial inflammatory changes in the colonic mucosa.

 

Ref: Page no-292, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and distension. He reports having constipation for the past week and has not passed gas or stool in the past 2 days. On examination, his abdomen is distended and tympanic to percussion. Digital rectal examination reveals a full rectal vault with hard stool. The patient's abdominal radiograph is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sigmoid volvulus

 

Option A:

 

The 'coffee-bean sign' (also known as the 'kidney bean sign' or 'bent inner tube sign') is a sign on an abdominal plain radiograph of a sigmoid volvulus.

 

Caecal volvulus may be mistaken with sigmoid volvulus.

 

Sigmoid volvulus – The radiograph would typically show a 'coffee bean sign' indicative of twisted bowel loops, aligning with the patient’s symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Diverticulosis: Usually asymptomatic, but can present with abdominal pain or complications such as diverticulitis, not typically causing complete constipation and a 'coffee bean sign'.

 

Option C. Intussusception: Usually presents with episodic pain and a 'target sign' on ultrasound, not typically seen on plain radiograph in adults.

 

Option D. Ileocecal TB: Would show thickening of the ileocecal region and enlarged lymph nodes but does not explain the radiographic findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a 'coffee bean sign' on the abdominal radiograph along with symptoms of severe abdominal pain and obstruction suggests a sigmoid volvulus, which is a twisting of the sigmoid colon that can lead to bowel obstruction.

 

 

Ref: Page no-306, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 1-day-old male infant presents to the emergency department with symptoms of abdominal distention, vomiting, and bilious vomit. The baby's mother reports that the baby has been feeding poorly since birth and has not passed any meconium stool. The baby appears irritable, with a distended abdomen and visible peristalsis. The healthcare team orders immediate imaging studies and consultation with a pediatric surgeon. The upper GI contrast study is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Midgut volvulus

 

Option C:

 

Midgut volvulus is a surgical emergency that can occur as a complication of malrotated bowel. Radiological findings include:

 

Contrast study-Corkscrew sign of twisted bowel as shown in the contrast study

CECT- Whirlpool sign" of twisted mesentery, malrotated bowel configuration, an inverted SMA/SMV relationship, and bowel obstruction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Typically presents with a 'double bubble' sign on imaging due to obstruction at the level of the duodenum, not involving twisting of the bowel as seen in the image.

 

Option B. Intussusception: Occurs more commonly in older children and would typically present with a 'target sign' on ultrasound, not involving twisting of the bowel.

 

Option D: Hirschsprung disease – Characterized by colonic obstruction due to absence of ganglion cells, typically not presenting with twisting of the bowel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Midgut volvulus, characterized by the 'corkscrew sign' on contrast study, is a surgical emergency that requires prompt intervention to prevent bowel ischemia and necrosis.

 

 

Ref: Page no-400, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text:
On x-ray, small bowel can be differentiated by large bowel by having:

 

  1. String of beads sign
  2. Haustrations
  3. Peripherally placed dilated bowel loops
  4. Air fluid level
  5. Valvulae conniventes
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1,4,5

 

Option D:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option D: (1,4,5) refers to the string of beads sign, air fluid levels, and valvulae conniventes, which are accurate identifiers of the small bowel on an X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The string of beads signs, air fluid levels, and valvulae conniventes are all distinctive features used to identify the small bowel on an X-ray.

 

 

Ref: Page no-284, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

choices.text: Reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries
Stands for extended Focused assessment with sonography in trauma
Not reliable in patients with subcutaneous emphysema
Indicated in all stable and unstable patients

questions.text: All of the following are true about e-FAST except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries

 

Option A:

 

Suggests that e-FAST is reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries. This is incorrect because e-FAST cannot reliably detect mesenteric injuries, which often require additional imaging such as a CT scan.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: States that e-FAST stands for extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma, which is correct. It is an extended form of the FAST exam that also includes evaluation for pneumothorax.

 

Option C: Asserts that e-FAST is not reliable in patients with subcutaneous emphysema. This is true because subcutaneous air can hinder the transmission of ultrasound waves, making the assessment unreliable.

 

Option D: Says that e-FAST is indicated in all stable and unstable patients, which is true. It is a rapid initial assessment tool for trauma patients to help identify the presence of free fluids that might require surgical intervention.

 

Limitations of FAST include-

 

  • Diaphragm tears
  • Retroperitoneal haemorrhage
  • Bowel injuries
  • Mesenteric injuries
  • Minor injuries(<200ml)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and obesity

 

Educational Objective:

 

e-FAST is not reliable for ruling out mesenteric injuries, as these injuries do not always produce free fluid or air and may be missed without more definitive imaging like a CT scan.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition(2018)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by ambulance following a motor vehicle accident. On arrival, the patient is alert and oriented but appears in distress and complaining of severe abdominal pain. He has multiple abrasions and contusions on his chest and abdomen. His vital signs are stable except for a mildly elevated heart rate. The trauma team initiates an extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (e-FAST) as given below. What will be your interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fast positive

 

Option B:

 

In the image given in the question, anechoic fluid is seen between the liver and kidney (the hepatorenal pouch of Morrison), which is suggestive of hemoperitoneum in a trauma setting.

 

(FAST positive) indicates the presence of free fluid, such as blood, in the abdominal cavity. Given the clinical context and the ultrasound findings of anechoic fluid in the hepatorenal pouch, this is the correct interpretation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: FAST negative would indicate no evidence of free fluid or other abnormalities on the ultrasound, which is not consistent with the presence of anechoic fluid seen in the image.

 

Option C: FAST inconclusive would suggest that the ultrasound results are uncertain or difficult to interpret, which is not the case here given the clear visualization of fluid.

 

Option D: Fast is incomplete as it stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma, but without specifying whether it is positive, negative, or inconclusive, it does not represent an answer to the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct interpretation of the e-FAST in this clinical scenario is FAST positive, indicative of a hemoperitoneum due to the visualization of anechoic fluid in the hepatorenal pouch, which is consistent with hemoperitoneum in a trauma patient.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the emergency department with chest pain and difficulty swallowing. She reports that the pain feels like it is in the center of her chest and is accompanied by a feeling of pressure. She also reports difficulty swallowing solid food, which feels like it gets stuck in her chest. On examination, the patient is in distress and appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Auscultation of the chest reveals no abnormal breath sounds. Electrocardiogram (ECG) is normal. Laboratory studies are unremarkable. A barium swallow study is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Diffuse oesophageal spasm

 

Option C:

 

The given barium swallow shows a corkscrew appearance of the esophagus. This is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm.

 

Esophageal manometry, which measures the strength and coordination of esophageal contractions is the gold standard for DES.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Achalasia cardia would be suggested by a barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance at the distal esophagus, with absent peristalsis and possible dilation of the proximal esophagus, which is not the case here.

 

Option B: Esophageal diverticula would typically show an outpouching or sac-like projection from the esophagus on imaging, which does not match the corkscrew pattern seen.

 

Option D: Esophageal carcinoma might show irregular narrowing or a mass effect on barium swallow, but would not typically result in a corkscrew pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis is Diffuse esophageal spasm, indicated by a corkscrew appearance of the esophagus on a barium swallow study, representative of non-peristaltic contractions of the esophagus.

 

Ref: Page no-248, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A young woman presented to the OPD with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. She was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia 3 months back. Barium swallow was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome

 

Option D:

 

The clinical presentation in this case, combined with the observation of an esophageal web on a barium swallow, suggests the presence of Plummer-Vinson syndrome, also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome.

 

Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by dysphagia due to esophageal webs, iron-deficiency anemia, and atrophic glossitis. These webs are formed by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the esophageal lumen, causing constriction. They are typically located near the cricopharyngeus muscle in the cervical esophagus arising from the anterior wall. They are never seen on the posterior wall.

 

It is a recognized risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of the post cricoid hypopharynx. 

 

(Plummer-Vinson syndrome) is characterized by the triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. It fits the clinical and radiographic presentation provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Esophageal carcinoma typically presents with progressive dysphagia and weight loss. The barium swallow may show irregular narrowing or a stricture, which differs from the thin mucosal projection seen in the image.

 

Option B: Zenker's diverticulum would present with a barium swallow showing an outpouching just above the esophagus' upper sphincter, which is not consistent with the finding of an esophageal web.

 

Option C: Esophageal leiomyoma is a smooth muscle tumor that could cause obstruction but would show as a mass on barium swallow, not a thin web.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most probable diagnosis is Plummer-Vinson Syndrome, indicated by dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and the presence of an esophageal web on barium swallow, typical for this syndrome.

 

Ref: Page no-244, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: What dye is used for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Iohexol

 

Option B:

 

Iohexol is the contrast agent utilized in the diagnostic evaluation of suspected esophageal perforation, whereas Gastrograffin, which is water-soluble, was previously used but has a significant risk of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema, making it unpopular now. Additionally, barium contrast is avoided in esophageal perforation cases since it triggers inflammation of the mediastinum associated with barium.

 

Iohexol is a nonionic, water-soluble contrast medium that is currently preferred for evaluating suspected esophageal perforations due to its lower risk of causing adverse reactions if aspirated compared to Gastrograffin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gastrograffin is a water-soluble contrast agent that was previously used but is now less preferred due to the risk of causing aspiration pneumonitis if aspirated.

 

Option C: Gadolinium is primarily used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and is not appropriate for evaluating esophageal perforations.

 

Option D: Barium sulfate is a contrast agent used in various radiographic studies, but it is not recommended for suspected esophageal perforation due to the risk of causing mediastinitis if leakage into the mediastinum occurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct answer is Iohexol, which is the contrast agent of choice in the diagnostic evaluation of suspected esophageal perforation because it minimizes the risk of complications compared to other contrast agents.

 

Ref: Page no-238, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: Diagnose the barium swallow as shown below
questions.solution:
Ans. A. B ring

 

Option A:

 

Schatzki ring is a symptomatic condition that occurs in the distal esophagus and is often associated with a hiatus hernia.

 

(B ring) refers to the Schatzki ring, a mucosal ring that occurs at the gastroesophageal junction and is associated with symptoms when tight enough to impede food passage. It's often associated with a sliding hiatal hernia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: A ring refers to a mucosal or muscular structure above the B ring, which is typically asymptomatic and does not usually impede the passage of a barium swallow.

 

Option C: Esophageal web is a thin protrusion of tissue into the lumen of the esophagus, typically located in the upper esophagus and can be associated with conditions like Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

 

Option D: Esophageal stricture refers to a narrowing of the esophagus that can be caused by various factors such as chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and would show a gradual tapering rather than a discrete ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis is B ring, also known as Schatzki ring, which is a symptomatic mucosal ring located at the squamocolumnar junction, typically associated with a hiatal hernia.

 

 

Ref: Page no-238, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: The given barium finding is characteristically seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. GERD  

 

Option D:

 

The given image is a barium swallow X-ray showing a feline esophagus suggestive of reflux esophagitis.

 

The appearance is almost always associated with active gastroesophageal reflux. The findings are transient, seen following reflux and not during swallowing. The appearance is confined to the distal two-thirds of the thoracic esophagus.

 

An important differential for the same is eosinophilic esophagitis.

 

GERD can present with a reticular pattern on barium swallow, known as a feline esophagus, due to transient contraction waves from reflux, which fits the description of the findings in the image provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Caustic injury often presents with more severe changes on imaging, such as extensive narrowing, ulceration, or irregularities due to the corrosive damage to the esophageal lining.

 

Option B: Barrett's esophagus may show changes in the distal esophagus on endoscopy, but a barium swallow might not be specific in identifying Barrett's esophagus. It is diagnosed by endoscopic observation of metaplastic columnar epithelium and confirmed with biopsy.

 

Option C: Steakhouse syndrome refers to a condition where a bolus of food (often meat) becomes lodged in the esophagus. This wouldn't present with the striped appearance seen in the image but rather an obstruction or hold up of barium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The barium swallow image shows findings suggestive of reflux esophagitis, characterized by a transient reticular pattern in the distal esophagus, often associated with GERD.

 


 

Figure 1 Endoscopic view of Feline Esophagus seen in Reflux Esophagitis

 

 

Figure 2 Feline esophagus seen in Reflux Esophagitis

 

Ref: Page no-238, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A neonate is admitted to NICU. His abdominal X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trisomy 21

 

Option B:

 

The given abdominal x-ray shows the double bubble sign, which is suggestive of duodenal atresia.

 

The double bubble sign represents the dilatation of the proximal duodenum and stomach. It can also be detected antenatally by ultrasound.

 

It is more common in infants with Down syndrome than in the general population, occurring in approximately 5-8% of newborns with Down syndrome.

 

Trisomy 21 is commonly associated with duodenal atresia, which is suggested by the "double bubble" sign visible on the X-ray, a classic indicator of this condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Trisomy 18 often presents with various congenital anomalies but is not specifically associated with the radiological sign indicated in the X-ray.

 

Option C: Monosomy X, also known as Turner syndrome, involves a different set of clinical features and is not particularly associated with duodenal atresia.

 

Option D: Trisomy 13 is associated with several congenital abnormalities but, like Trisomy 18, it does not have a strong correlation with the "double bubble" sign as does Trisomy 21.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray shows a "double bubble" sign, suggestive of duodenal atresia, which is more commonly found in infants with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), occurring in approximately 5-8% of newborns with this condition.

 

 

Ref: Page no-396, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: Identify the type of Investigation shown in this radiograph?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Barium meal

 

Option B:

    

The given image is a double contrast radiograph of barium meal. It is used to examine the lower half of the esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

 

Barium meal involves an examination of the stomach and duodenum with barium contrast, which is consistent with the extensive visualization of these areas in the image

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Barium swallow is an examination of the pharynx and esophagus using barium contrast, which would not typically show the stomach or duodenum.

 

Option C: Barium meal follow through includes not just the stomach and duodenum but also the small intestines over time. The image doesn't indicate that the small intestines are being evaluated over time.

 

Option D: Barium enema is an examination of the colon and rectum using barium contrast introduced through the rectum, which would not show the upper gastrointestinal structures seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiograph shown is of a Barium meal, a double contrast study used to visualize the lower half of the esophagus, the stomach, and the entire duodenum.

 

 

Ref: Page no-254, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-year-old child who suddenly develops severe, intermittent abdominal pain associated with vomiting and bloody stools. An USG was done as shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intussusception

 

Option A:

 

The given ultrasound abdomen depicts the target sign suggestive of intussusception.

 

The target sign is due to concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by the mucosa and muscularis. The hypoechoic bands are formed by the submucosa.

 

Intussusception presents with the classic ultrasound finding of the target sign, due to the telescoping of one part of the intestine into another, creating multiple layers that appear as concentric rings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Acute appendicitis typically shows a noncompressible, blind-ending tubular structure on ultrasound, which may not have the characteristic target or donut sign seen in intussusception.

 

Option C: Meckel's diverticulum can cause complications that may lead to symptoms similar to intussusception, but it would not create the target sign on ultrasound.

 

Option D: Midgut volvulus may present with severe abdominal symptoms, but the sonographic findings usually include a 'whirlpool sign', representing twisted mesentery and bowel, rather than the target sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis is Intussusception, indicated by the ultrasound appearance of the target sign, which is characteristic of this condition.

 

NOTE – Rotavirus vaccination is associated with Intussusception

 

Ref: Page no-284, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with abdominal cramping, fever, and watery diarrhea. She recently completed a course of antibiotics for a urinary tract infection. Stool culture is negative for bacterial pathogens, but stool toxin assay is positive. His CT abdomen was performed which is given below. What is the patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pseudomembranous colitis

 

Option D:

 

The CT image shows the characteristic accordion sign, which is a finding seen in pseudomembranous colitis. The term accordion is used to describe the thickened edematous bowel that resembles the folds of the musical instrument.

 

The appearance is due to the hyperemic enhancing mucosa stretched over the thickened submucosal folds and is also observed when the contrast is trapped between the edematous haustral folds and pseudo membranes of the colon. It is commonly associated with Clostridium difficile infection.

 

(Pseudomembranous colitis) is commonly associated with Clostridium difficile infection, especially following antibiotic use, and presents with the accordion sign on CT imaging, characterized by thickened, edematous bowel walls with a haustral pattern that resembles an accordion. This is consistent with the clinical scenario and imaging findings

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Crohn's disease typically shows on CT as segmental bowel wall thickening, strictures, and the presence of "skip lesions." The accordion sign is not characteristic of Crohn's disease.

 

Option B: Ulcerative colitis usually presents with continuous colonic involvement starting from the rectum with uniform wall thickening and loss of haustral pattern on CT. It does not typically present with the accordion sign.

 

Option C: (Toxic megacolon) is a severe complication of colitis, marked by extreme dilation of the colon on imaging, along with signs of systemic toxicity. While wall thickening may be present, the accordion sign is not the defining feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CT image showing the accordion sign, along with the clinical presentation of recent antibiotic use, diarrhea, positive stool toxin assay, and fever, strongly suggests the diagnosis of Pseudomembranous colitis associated with Clostridium difficile infection.

 

Ref: Page no-294, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with complaints of abdominal pain, bloating, and changes in bowel habits over the past few months. Physical examination is unremarkable, and laboratory tests show no abnormalities. A barium enema study was done and is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoma colon

 

Option C:

 

The clinical scenario provided, combined with the observation of the apple core sign on the barium study, indicates the possibility of colon carcinoma. The apple core sign, also known as the napkin ring sign, refers to a distinctive pattern of irregular narrowing of a short segment of the large bowel. This narrowing is characterized by shouldered margins that resemble the shape of an apple core. This sign is typically observed during a contrast enema study and is almost always indicative of an annular colon carcinoma causing stenosis.

 

(Carcinoma colon) is often identified by the apple core sign on a barium enema, which indicates a constricting annular lesion with shouldered margins, fitting the image provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: (Ileocecal TB) often presents with findings in the ileocecal region, such as strictures or a pulled-up cecum. It is less likely to show the concentric narrowing seen in the barium enema image.

 

Option B: Irritable bowel syndrome is a functional disorder characterized by symptoms like abdominal pain and altered bowel habits. It cannot be diagnosed through imaging, as it typically shows no abnormalities on a barium enema.

 

Option D: Sigmoid diverticulosis would show multiple outpouchings (diverticula) in the sigmoid colon on a barium enema, which is not consistent with the apple core sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis is Carcinoma colon, indicated by the apple core sign on the barium enema, which reflects a segmental constriction consistent with an annular colon carcinoma.

 

Ref: Page no-300, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with a history of constipation since birth. The mother reports that the baby has infrequent bowel movements, and when he does pass stool, it is hard and pellet-like. The infant is otherwise healthy, with no other significant medical history. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen, and a rectal examination reveals an empty rectum. A barium enema was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hirschsprung's disease

 

Option B:

 

The given clinical scenario along with the barium study is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease.

 

The image depicts barium enema showing dilated sigmoid colon with a transition zone.

 

The most important sign on barium enema is a sudden change of caliber from the narrow aganglionic segment and dilated proximal bowel.

 

Hirschsprung disease is characterized by aganglionosis (absence of ganglion cells) in the distal colon and rectum due to loss of RET gene. This is due to failure of neural crest cells to migrate into bowel segments. It affects cells both in the myenteric and submucosal plexuses. Hence, functional obstruction develops because of a spasm in the enervated colon.

 

Hirschsprung's disease is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel, which leads to a functional obstruction. The barium enema would show a transition zone between the narrow aganglionic segment and the dilated normal bowel proximal to it, which is depicted in the image provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anal atresia is a congenital absence of an opening at the bottom end of the intestinal tract. Barium enema would not be able to pass beyond the atresia, and it would not show a transition zone.

 

Option C: Meconium ileus occurs when the small intestine is obstructed by thick, sticky meconium. It's often associated with cystic fibrosis, and barium enema would show inspissated meconium within the ileum.

 

Option D: Meconium plug syndrome also involves obstruction of the bowel by meconium, but the barium enema usually shows large meconium plugs that can be relieved by the enema itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most probable diagnosis is Hirschsprung's disease, indicated by the clinical presentation of constipation since birth and the characteristic radiological finding of a transition zone on barium enema due to aganglionosis of the rectosigmoid colon.

 

Ref: Page no-402, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a low-grade fever associated with loss of appetite and weight loss. A barium meal follow-through was done and is as shown. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ileocecal TB

 

Option A:

 

Based on the given clinical scenario and the barium study findings, the patient is likely suffering from ileocecal tuberculosis. The barium study revealed several characteristic features of this condition, including a dilated proximal ileum, narrowed terminal ileum with a string sign, and a shrunken cecum that appears pulled up away from the right iliac fossa. The ileocecal junction, which is the most common site of tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract, is also narrowed.

 

Barium meal follow-through study findings in ileocecal tuberculosis are:

 

Dilatation of proximal ileum

Narrowed terminal ileum: string sign

Gooseneck ileus - ileum hanging from pulled up caecum

Caecum appears shrunken and pulled up away from the right iliac fossa

Fleischner sign (also known as the inverted umbrella sign), refers to a widely gaping, thickened, patulous ileocecal valve and a narrowed, ulcerated terminal ileum

 

Ileocecal TB typically presents with imaging features such as dilatation of the proximal ileum, a narrowed terminal ileum with a string sign, and a shrunken, pulled-up cecum, which is consistent with the description provided. These are classic radiographic findings for tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract, particularly at the ileocecal junction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Colonic diverticulosis would show pouch-like outpouchings in the colon and doesn’t usually present with the narrowing or pulling up of the cecum.

 

Option C: Crohn's disease can present with similar features to ileocecal TB, including strictures and bowel wall thickening, but Crohn's typically shows more segmental involvement with "skip lesions" and the presence of fistulas or abscesses.

 

Option D: Carcinoma of the cecum would more likely present with an irregular mass or apple-core lesion on barium studies, which is not described in the given explanation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The findings from the barium meal follow-through, along with the clinical symptoms, suggest a diagnosis of Ileocecal TB, characterized by a dilated proximal ileum, narrowed terminal ileum with a string sign, and a shrunken, pulled-up cecum.

 

Ref: Page no-278, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe left upper quadrant (LUQ) pain after being punched by his colleague in a fight. His blood pressure is 110/76mmHg, his pulse is 80 bpm, and his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. Which of the following will be the best investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CT of the abdomen

 

Option D:

 

Based on the clinical presentation of severe left upper quadrant (LUQ) pain after being punched, there is a high suspicion of abdominal trauma. The patient's vital signs are relatively stable, but given the mechanism of injury, it is important to rule out any significant intra-abdominal injuries.

 

CT of the abdomen is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating abdominal trauma in stable patients.

 

CT of the abdomen provides a comprehensive evaluation of abdominal organs and structures and is the gold standard for stable patients with suspected intra-abdominal trauma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Peritoneal lavage: Previously used in the assessment of blunt abdominal trauma, now largely replaced by more advanced imaging.

 

Option B. Upper GI series: Typically used for evaluating the upper gastrointestinal tract, not for acute trauma assessment.

 

Option C. E-FAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma): A rapid bedside ultrasound examination to evaluate for free fluid and air; useful in trauma but may not be as definitive as a CT scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality for evaluating abdominal trauma in stable patients, providing detailed assessment to rule out significant internal injuries.

 

Approach to Blunt trauma abdomen

 

 

Ref: Page no-386, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain after eating a piece of steak. The pain started suddenly and radiates to his back. He also reports difficulty swallowing, and is drooling saliva. His vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lower chest and upper abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Esophageal perforation

 

Option C:

 

The sudden onset of severe chest pain, difficulty swallowing, and drooling of saliva, along with the physical examination findings of tenderness over the lower chest and upper abdomen, are suggestive of esophageal perforation. The chest x-ray findings of mediastinal widening and subcutaneous emphysema further support this diagnosis.

 

Esophageal perforation can be caused by a variety of factors, including trauma, instrumentation, and underlying esophageal disease.

 

Treatment typically involves immediate surgical intervention to repair the perforation and prevent the development of potentially life-threatening complications such as mediastinitis or sepsis.

 

Esophageal perforation – Can present with sudden severe chest pain, difficulty swallowing, and salivation, often after eating something that could cause trauma to the esophagus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Often presents with chest pain and difficulty breathing, but wouldn’t typically cause difficulty swallowing or drooling.

 

Option B. Acute coronary syndrome: Characterized by chest pain that may radiate to the back, it wouldn't typically cause symptoms related to swallowing.

 

Option D. Acute gastritis: Can cause chest pain and tenderness but is not typically associated with swallowing difficulties or the radiographic signs seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of severe chest pain after eating, along with swallowing difficulties and radiographic signs of air in the soft tissues, suggests an esophageal perforation, which requires prompt medical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no-238, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, distension, and vomiting. The patient reports that the pain started suddenly and has been getting progressively worse over the past few hours. The patient has a history of previous abdominal surgeries, including a cholecystectomy.

 

On examination, the patient has a distended abdomen with visible peristalsis. The bowel sounds are hyperactive, and there is tenderness on palpation in the periumbilical region. A plain abdominal X-ray is shown here. What is the likely site of obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Jejunum

 

Option D:

 

The X-ray shows dilated small bowel loops with complete mucosa; folds known as valvulae conniventes - Suggestive of Jejunum.

 

Jejunum is indicated by the presence of dilated loops of bowel centrally located with prominent valvulae conniventes, as seen in the X-ray, fitting the description of the findings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ileum would typically show featureless loops of bowel because the valvulae conniventes are less prominent in the ileum compared to the jejunum. This does not align with the X-ray findings.

 

Option B: Duodenum can show dilation in cases of obstruction, but the presence of mucosal folds in the X-ray image would be unusual for duodenal obstruction, as the duodenum has a less distinct pattern of folds.

 

Option C: Transverse colon would present with haustrations and a location more peripherally in the abdomen on X-ray, not centrally, as seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray indicates dilated small bowel loops with prominent mucosal folds (valvulae conniventes) suggestive of a jejunal obstruction.

 

 

Ref: Page no-284, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)
